batchMetadata.description: Foundational accounting concepts, definitions, and basic journal entries

questions.question: The basic accounting equation is:
questions.explanation: The basic accounting equation is Assets = Liabilities + Equity. This fundamental equation must always balance and forms the basis for double-entry bookkeeping.
questions.tip: A = L + E. This equation must always balance after every transaction.

questions.question: What is the normal balance of an asset account?
questions.explanation: Asset accounts have a normal debit balance. Assets increase with debits and decrease with credits. This is a fundamental rule of double-entry bookkeeping.
questions.tip: Assets and Expenses = Debit normal balance. Liabilities, Equity, Revenue = Credit normal balance.

questions.question: To increase a liability account, you would:
questions.explanation: Liability accounts increase with credits and decrease with debits. Liabilities have a normal credit balance.
questions.tip: Liabilities increase with credits (same side as equity on the accounting equation).

questions.question: Revenue accounts have a normal:
questions.explanation: Revenue accounts have a normal credit balance. Revenue increases equity, and since equity has a credit balance, revenue also has a credit balance.
questions.tip: Revenue increases equity. Equity is credit. So revenue is credit.

questions.question: Expense accounts have a normal:
questions.explanation: Expense accounts have a normal debit balance. Expenses decrease equity, so they work opposite to equity's credit balance.
questions.tip: Expenses decrease equity (opposite of revenue). Debit normal balance.

questions.question: In a journal entry, which is recorded first?

options.D: The account with the longest name

questions.explanation: In standard journal entry format, debits are recorded first (listed first, on the left), followed by credits (indented, on the right). Total debits must equal total credits.
questions.tip: Standard format: Debits listed first, Credits indented below. Debits = Credits.

questions.question: Which of the following appears on the balance sheet?
questions.explanation: Accounts payable is a liability and appears on the balance sheet. Revenue, cost of goods sold, and sales discounts are income statement items.
questions.tip: Balance sheet: Assets, Liabilities, Equity. Income statement: Revenues and Expenses.

questions.question: Which of the following appears on the income statement?
questions.explanation: Depreciation expense is an expense and appears on the income statement. Retained earnings, accounts receivable, and common stock are balance sheet items.
questions.tip: Income statement shows revenues and expenses. Depreciation is an expense.

questions.question: Under accrual accounting, revenue is recognized when:
questions.explanation: Under accrual accounting and ASC 606, revenue is recognized when the performance obligation is satisfied (goods delivered or services performed), regardless of when cash is received.
questions.tip: Accrual = When earned (performance obligation satisfied). Cash basis = When cash received.

questions.question: Under accrual accounting, expenses are recognized when:
questions.explanation: Under accrual accounting, expenses are recognized when incurred, which is when the benefit is received or the obligation arises, not necessarily when cash is paid.
questions.tip: Expenses recognized when incurred (matching principle), not when paid.

questions.question: A current asset is one that will be converted to cash or used within:

options.B: 1 year or the operating cycle, whichever is longer

questions.explanation: Current assets are those expected to be converted to cash, sold, or consumed within one year or the operating cycle, whichever is longer.
questions.tip: Current = Within 1 year or operating cycle (whichever is longer).

questions.question: Which is a current liability?
questions.explanation: Accounts payable due in 30 days is a current liability because it will be paid within one year. The other options are long-term (noncurrent) liabilities.
questions.tip: Current liabilities are due within 1 year or operating cycle.

questions.question: Retained earnings increases when a company has:
questions.explanation: Retained earnings increases with net income and decreases with net losses and dividend payments. It represents accumulated earnings not distributed to shareholders.
questions.tip: RE increases with income, decreases with losses and dividends.

questions.question: When a company pays cash dividends, retained earnings:
questions.explanation: Cash dividends reduce retained earnings because they represent a distribution of accumulated earnings to shareholders.
questions.tip: Dividends are distributions to owners, reducing retained earnings.

questions.question: Depreciation is the process of:

options.B: Allocating the cost of an asset over its useful life

questions.explanation: Depreciation is the systematic allocation of the cost of a tangible asset over its useful life. It is not a valuation method but a cost allocation process.
questions.tip: Depreciation = Cost allocation over useful life, not valuation.

questions.question: Equipment costs $10,000 with a $2,000 salvage value and 4-year life. What is annual straight-line depreciation?
questions.explanation: Straight-line depreciation = (Cost - Salvage) / Life = ($10,000 - $2,000) / 4 = $2,000 per year.
questions.tip: SL Depreciation = (Cost - Salvage) / Useful Life

questions.question: Inventory is classified as a:
questions.explanation: Inventory is a current asset because it is expected to be sold within the normal operating cycle of the business.
questions.tip: Inventory = Current asset (expected to be sold within operating cycle).

questions.question: Under FIFO (First-In, First-Out), which inventory is assumed sold first?

options.D: A weighted average of all inventory

questions.explanation: Under FIFO, the oldest (first-in) inventory costs are assumed to be sold first. The newest costs remain in ending inventory.
questions.tip: FIFO: Oldest costs go to COGS, newest costs stay in ending inventory.

questions.question: Accounts receivable represents:

options.A: Amounts the company owes to suppliers
options.B: Amounts customers owe to the company

questions.explanation: Accounts receivable represents amounts owed to the company by customers for goods or services sold on credit. It is an asset.
questions.tip: A/R = Money customers owe us (asset). A/P = Money we owe suppliers (liability).

questions.question: Accounts payable represents:

options.B: Amounts the company owes to suppliers

questions.explanation: Accounts payable represents amounts the company owes to suppliers for goods or services purchased on credit. It is a liability.
questions.tip: A/P = Money we owe suppliers for credit purchases (liability).

questions.question: Prepaid insurance is classified as:
questions.explanation: Prepaid insurance is an asset because it represents future economic benefit - insurance coverage that has been paid for but not yet used.
questions.tip: Prepaid = Asset (future benefit paid in advance).

questions.question: Unearned revenue is classified as:
questions.explanation: Unearned revenue (deferred revenue) is a liability because it represents an obligation to provide goods or services in the future for payment already received.
questions.tip: Unearned revenue = Liability (we owe the customer goods/services).

questions.question: A company has revenues of $100,000 and expenses of $75,000. What is net income?
questions.explanation: Net income = Revenues - Expenses = $100,000 - $75,000 = $25,000.
questions.tip: Net Income = Revenues - Expenses

questions.question: Current assets are $50,000 and current liabilities are $30,000. What is working capital?
questions.explanation: Working capital = Current Assets - Current Liabilities = $50,000 - $30,000 = $20,000.
questions.tip: Working Capital = Current Assets - Current Liabilities

questions.question: Current assets are $80,000 and current liabilities are $40,000. What is the current ratio?
questions.explanation: Current ratio = Current Assets / Current Liabilities = $80,000 / $40,000 = 2.0
questions.tip: Current Ratio = Current Assets / Current Liabilities. Higher is generally better.

questions.question: Accumulated depreciation is a:
questions.explanation: Accumulated depreciation is a contra asset account. It has a credit balance and reduces the related asset account (property, plant, and equipment) to show net book value.
questions.tip: Contra accounts have opposite normal balances. Accumulated depreciation (credit) reduces assets (debit).

questions.question: Equipment cost $50,000 with accumulated depreciation of $20,000. What is the net book value?
questions.explanation: Net book value = Cost - Accumulated Depreciation = $50,000 - $20,000 = $30,000.
questions.tip: Book Value = Cost - Accumulated Depreciation

questions.question: Adjusting entries are made to:

options.A: Correct errors in the cash account
options.B: Record revenues and expenses in the proper period

questions.explanation: Adjusting entries ensure that revenues and expenses are recorded in the proper accounting period under accrual accounting. They are made at the end of each period before preparing financial statements.
questions.tip: Adjusting entries = Record revenues/expenses in correct period (accrual basis).

questions.question: Closing entries are made to:

options.B: Transfer balances from temporary accounts to retained earnings

questions.explanation: Closing entries transfer balances from temporary accounts (revenues, expenses, dividends) to retained earnings at the end of each period, resetting temporary accounts to zero for the next period.
questions.tip: Closing entries: Transfer Revenue, Expenses, Dividends to Retained Earnings. Reset temporaries to zero.

questions.question: Which is a temporary account?
questions.explanation: Sales Revenue is a temporary account that is closed to retained earnings at the end of each period. Cash, accounts payable, and retained earnings are permanent accounts that carry forward.
questions.tip: Temporary: Revenues, Expenses, Dividends (closed each period). Permanent: Assets, Liabilities, Equity.

questions.question: The purpose of a trial balance is to:

options.B: Verify that total debits equal total credits

questions.explanation: A trial balance lists all accounts and their balances to verify that total debits equal total credits. It helps detect errors but does not guarantee accounts are correct.
questions.tip: Trial balance: Debits must equal Credits. Doesn't guarantee accuracy, just balance.

questions.question: Sales are $200,000 and cost of goods sold is $120,000. What is gross profit?
questions.explanation: Gross Profit = Sales - Cost of Goods Sold = $200,000 - $120,000 = $80,000.
questions.tip: Gross Profit = Sales - COGS

questions.question: GAAP stands for:
questions.explanation: GAAP stands for Generally Accepted Accounting Principles, which are the standard framework of accounting rules and guidelines used in the United States.
questions.tip: GAAP = Generally Accepted Accounting Principles. Set by FASB for US companies.

questions.question: Which organization sets accounting standards for nongovernmental entities in the US?
questions.explanation: The Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) is the designated organization for establishing accounting standards for nongovernmental entities in the United States.
questions.tip: FASB = Standard setter for US GAAP. GASB = Government accounting. IASB = International (IFRS).

questions.question: A fiscal year is:

options.D: The same as a calendar quarter

questions.explanation: A fiscal year is any 12-month period used for accounting purposes. While many companies use the calendar year (Jan 1 - Dec 31), others use different 12-month periods (e.g., July 1 - June 30).
questions.tip: Fiscal year = Any 12-month period. Doesn't have to match calendar year.
